Hello and welcome to the <#993005932902613103> channel <:nfteth:822186186016948314> 

Feel free to reach out to the Lit Protocol Team at any point with your questions! 

Just giving you all a quick snapshot for you to get quickly acquainted!


üëÄ **ABOUT** 
**Lit** is a decentralized compute, encryption, and access control network powered by threshold cryptography.

With Lit, developers can automate signing, reading, and writing data to web3 decentralized networks like Ethereum and IPFS. Additionally, data can be private in these open web applications and only decrypted by authorized parties with Lit access control. 

Lit offers two products, Prograblem Key Pairs (PKPs) and Decentralized Access Control. There is one bounty for each product!


üèÜ **PRIZE OVERVIEW **

üîë Best use of Key Pair Apps + Tools ‚Äî $2500
ü•∑ Private Data on the Open Web ‚Äî $2500

**‚Üì Full Prize Breakdown Here ‚Üì **
https://ethglobal.com/events/hackfs2022/prizes


üöÄ **WORKSHOP** 
*Workshop link coming soon!*


üîó **IMPORTANT LINKS**
https://developer.litprotocol.com/docs/litactionsandpkps/whatarelitactionsandpkps/
https://developer.litprotocol.com/docs/toolsandexamples/sdkexamples/encryptanddecrypt/installation/
Hello!
We are planning on building using the Lit Protocol, but would like to validate if our idea is possible to implement
Would there be any mentor that we could have a chat with?

~~Hi <@720407640131240026>  ü§ó which chains does lit support? I only see `ethereum` in the docs, or does that mean any EVM chain?~~
Nvm already found the answer (:

Hello I‚Äôm potentially interested in using lit to token gate content for virtual worlds stored on ipfs. How much does the encryption/decryption rely on centralized servers? Ie if lit disappears one day and my content is encrypted will I be able to decrypt it if lits servers are unavailable?

One use case I'm exploring needs to protect anyone but data owners(and people given permission to) from reading the full data but provide only insights from it. Is this sth Lit Protocol can help with?
Hi we are planning to build using Lit protocol  any  Lit Protocol  member for discuss about our project
yes! can you DM me?
Lit is a decentralized dependency. if a few of the nodes go away, you can still get the key. if all of them go away, you won't be able to.
please DM!
Yes! Check this out: https://developer.litprotocol.com/docs/AccessControlConditions/intro
<@708879198915395645>  can you please tell me what can we do with lit-protocol in simple words like examples of previous projects that are built on lit-protocols.

FYI, in the prizes section, under ü•∑ Private Data on the Open Web ‚Äî $2500
it says "For this bounty, create a novel tool or application that uses Lit to store private data on the open web. Check out this guide for tips on how to implement it."
There's no clickable link there.
thanks for catching!
here's the link: https://blog.litprotocol.com/?p=lit-x-bundlr-x-arweave-guide
will also update on prize site üôÇ
hi <@804718381814513695> can we share the key in a secure manner with other people to decrypt the content?
cool so if we have the key we can decrypt the content?

**Decentralized Access Control == Gated Access**
I like to think: Lit allows for easy "gated access" to things (information, events, finances)

examples:
You could store information that only those with an NFT from a particular collection can read/access/edit.
You could allow specified users to attend an online seminar.
Lit will provision the user a key to decrypt when their meet the conditions: https://developer.litprotocol.com/docs/AccessControlConditions/intro
yes, that's correct. the content is initially encrypted client side and the key that is generated during that process can decrypt.

Hello. While the tutorial are great to get something working, is there some kind of API reference available, too?
For example, here are a bunch of functions mentioned to use, but nothing about the parameter list and return type
https://developer.litprotocol.com/docs/ToolsAndExamples/SDKExamples/EncryptAndDecrypt/encryption#:~:text=If%20you%20are,use%20zipAndEncryptFiles()%20instead.
Found it: https://github.com/LIT-Protocol/lit-js-sdk/blob/main/api_docs.md
awesome.
ping if you've got other questions <@548176959293751338>
Thanks David üëç

<@708879198915395645> Question: When using the Lit Ceramic SDK, what Ceramic data model is being used here?:
```
const stringToEncrypt = 'This is what we want to encrypt on Lit and then store on ceramic'
const response = litCeramicIntegration
   .encryptAndWrite(stringToEncrypt, accessControlConditions)
   .then((streamID) => console.log(streamID))
```

it's a custom one that stores your data as an encrypted zip along with the metadata needed to decrypt it via Lit.  You can see it in the code here https://github.com/LIT-Protocol/CeramicIntegration/blob/main/src/ceramic.ts#L86
my string data is empty
this is the data when console logged
`checkAndSignAuthMessage` prompts for a sign every time, the docs says that it check in localStorage first doesn't seem to
this page link doesn't work
Thanks!
hey there
we want to store images in decentralized network
ideally from webbrowser
is it possible with your product?

here's an example <@436280197340463105>: https://blog.litprotocol.com/?p=lit-x-bundlr-x-arweave-guide

you can use Lit with any storage network!
we wanna  to avoid using secret keys and backend
can we safely use your api from frontend?
encryptedSymmetricKey should be passed in as hex.  looks like you're passing it in as an array. you can convert it with `LitJsSdk.uint8arrayToString(yourArrayHere, 'base16')`
are you using the same chain every time?  and you're sure you're not in an env where localstorage is restricted, like an iframe?
those docs are here now: https://developer.litprotocol.com/docs/AccessControlConditions/EVM/customContractCalls

yes you can do this, and Lit will handle key management for you, but you need to decide where you will store the images.  arweave?  ipfs?  Lit doesn't handle the storage side of this, we only encrypt and decrypt the data for you (client side)
I am on localhost
yeah it should work fine on localhost.  are you passing the same chain everytime?
yup, I am invoking `checkAndSignAuthMessage` on button click so on every button click it pops my metamask
and is it possible to get the connected address using the LitSdk object?

yeah it shouldn't do that.  but it will do that if you either change your chain, or wallet address.  like if you run checkAndSignAuthMessage and then change your wallet address in metamask, and run checkAndSignAuthMessage again, it will pop metamask again for a new signature.  otherwise, it should store and retrieve it from localstorage.  are you in chrome?
Yes
does this mean i don't meet the accessControl conditions or am I passing the wrong ones
2 accessControlConditions being sent during encryption and decryption don't know why is it not the same
i think it uses buffer which if not in browser then fails
and prompts to sign
is Lit supposed to be used on server-side? üòÖ
Can you show me the code for this?
It can be used on both

This repo is an example on encrypting static content and upload to a web3 storage (arweave), then pull it back down and decrypt it
https://github.com/LIT-Protocol/lit-bundlr-example/blob/e9ba2a46e1711389f71f435ee53c319454b61280/pages/index.js#L367

if you trace the function that is being used on each step, it should give you a clearer image of how lit encrypting works eg. step 1 > `onDropKey` step2 > `onDropFile` step3 > `onClickSetAccessControl` , etc.
This line might help: https://github.com/LIT-Protocol/lit-bundlr-example/blob/e9ba2a46e1711389f71f435ee53c319454b61280/pages/index.js#L185
Which line of your code does this error occur?
getEncryptionKey
first image
I am not storing the packagedData anywhere just directly calling decrypt after everything to check if it works
so basically the accessControl used for encrypt is passed along to the getEncryptionKey
so if `getEncryptionKey` failed, have you console.log each argument to check if they are correct?
let me try that

and check against the types suggested in the doc:
https://github.com/LIT-Protocol/lit-js-sdk/blob/main/api_docs.md#getencryptionkey
symmetric key is blank üòÖ
üòÑ
these uint8arrays are frustrating
üòÖ
this is how it looks like
this is what i am doing is this correct?
seems fine to me
returns empty string
which?
encryptedSymmetricKey after uint8arrayToString
is `data.encryptedSymmetricKey` empty?
no its a object
shown above
and what does `console.log(new Uint8Array(data.encryptedSymmetricKey))` gives you?
i guess it converts to nothing
this is where i am getting stuck again and again üòÖ
Have you tried removing `new Uint8Array` and just pass in `data.encryptedSymmetricKey`
this is what is returned from `saveEncryptionKey`
one of the examples has this comment

If you go back to your 
```
const encryptedSymmetricKey = await litNodeClient.saveEncryptionKey({
      accessControlConditions,
      symmetricKey,
      authSig,
      chain,
    });
```

and check it with:
```
const testToDecrypt = LitJsSdk.uint8arrayToString(encryptedSymmetricKey, "base16");
```

what does `testToDecrypt` console log to
and if you go back to this, does it give you the same thing?
no this returns empty string
This should give you the result of `testToDecrypt`, there's something wrong with your `encryptedSymmetricKey` at the decrypting part, you can check what's the difference between the 2
If you got a repo I can clone it to take a look
i haven't do you mind coming on a call I know its too much to ask üòÖ
the easiest i can think of is to store the hex version on the network
then directly use that
yea, sorry I can't at the moment.
Does `console.log(data.encryptedSymmetricKey)` gives you anything?
`data.encryptedSymmetricKey` should be the same as this

just a regular object

```
const test = new Uint8Array(Object.values(data.encryptedSymmetricKey));
```
check what test console .log to

I guess it works? lol

progress

encryption gave me a blob
yea, you will need to turn that into a string before putting it in `packagedData`

I have a uint8array
has anybody been able to succesfully encrypt and decrypt string üòÇ
i don't have a dataURI just a uint8array
what's the for loop for it is not even being used üòÖ

Hey, we are working on a dApp " StudyBuddy" that will facilitate the "on-boarding" of devs into web3 by providing an exchange marketplace for "knowledge" between developers :
- Hacker / developer can sell his NFT ( notes of course / hackathon etc ) to another dev and become his mentor and when this is done --> they can chat on p2p chat and help each other. 

I have a question : 

with Lit-Protocol is it possible to encrypt the data we will sell as NFT?

If you check the source code `./src/integration.ts` there's a function called `updateAccess` which accepts your `streamId` and `newAccessControlConditions` as params, I believe you can use that to update it
this link is broken. Missing /docs

Question around lit. We want to create tests where the results will be stored on IPFS. We obvs don't want people to be able to see the results if they share the ipfs hash. What would be the best way to encrypt the answers using Lit but where people passing the text can verify their answers?
thanks!!

You can store your encrypted answers on IPFS along with your access control conditions, chain, and encrypted symmetric key, so that when you pull the data down from IPFS, you can retrieve the symmetric key from the "getEncryptionKey" from the lit nodes to decrypt your answers
but how can we make sure our platform can cross check but other people can't? would we whitelist some addresses?
gm everyone!
Hi <@528729934789869596>, so it's safe to store the `encrypted symmetric key` in a place with public access? Like storing the zip file generated by `encryptFileAndZipWithMetadata`  in IPFS?

Yea, the encryptedSymmetricKey is, well, encrypted, so it can be public, check this demo out:
https://tinyurl.com/3ty3sbzb
okay, thank you <@528729934789869596>, I thought so, but just wanted to double check!

Hello team!

We're trying to figure out from the docs whether it is possible for one user to encrypt something with an access control that allows another user to decrypt.

Is this possible?
We figured it out everything works fine now!!!

Try to use this method: "eth_getBalance",
    parameters: [":userAddress", "latest"],
Not sure if I understood it correctly, but that's the entire point of Lit Protocol, you can set other wallet addresses to decrypt anything

Just need to understand how that works in the backend and what I need to check

You will probably need to convert it back to File/Blob

Hello and welcome to the <#993005932902613103> channel <:nfteth:822186186016948314> 

Feel free to reach out to the Lit Protocol Team at any point with your questions! 

Just giving you all a quick snapshot for you to get quickly acquainted!


üëÄ **ABOUT** 
**Lit** is a decentralized compute, encryption, and access control network powered by threshold cryptography.

With Lit, developers can automate signing, reading, and writing data to web3 decentralized networks like Ethereum and IPFS. Additionally, data can be private in these open web applications and only decrypted by authorized parties with Lit access control. 

Lit offers two products, Prograblem Key Pairs (PKPs) and Decentralized Access Control. There is one bounty for each product!


üèÜ **PRIZE OVERVIEW**

**For the three best uses of Lit in a creator application:**
ü•á $2,500
ü•à $1,500
ü•â $1,000

https://ethglobal.com/events/metabolism/prizes

<@399725459455213579> , <@708879198915395645> Can i use Polygon Mumbai as my chain?  i saw chain = "ethereum" what verb should i use to for Mumbai testnet???

<@399725459455213579> üëãüèº is there any hello-world like example for a simple interaction w/PKP? I've noticed most of the docs (https://developer.litprotocol.com/LitActionsAndPKPs/whatAreLitActionsAndPKPs) focuses on Lit Actions, but not much on PKP directly
Yes! Mumbai is a supported testnet: https://developer.litprotocol.com/supportedChains
Thanks

Additional question, I guess I can't ‚Äúschedule‚Äù actions within Lit Actions right? If I need an action I need to submit it myself manually but there's no easy way to ‚Äútrigger‚Äù this call automatically within the protocol network, correct?
you can use "mumbai" for mumbai

the only way to interface with PKPs right now is via lit actions.  but it's really easy to create a lit action that will sign whatever you want.  here's an example: https://github.com/LIT-Protocol/js-serverless-function-test/blob/main/js-sdkTests/helloworld.js
yes that's correct.  you could use Tenderly Actions to do this kind of scheduling right now.  hopefully we will offer this ourselves in the future
Gotcha, thanks! That's quite useful, I guess the `authSign` is always needed to verify "who" called the action, correct?

FWIW I'm thinking on messing around w/the concept of deploying NFT-wallets  via Lit Protocol like the ones described in the documentation, but I guess right now since we can't generate PKPs that might be not available
yup, but you can also authorize a ipfsID of some JS code (a lit action) and then the AuthSig doesn't matter
the other option was to see if there's some sort of PRG we could use within a LitAction to at least "embed" a wallet into the owner of a given NFT
Gotcha, was thinking in doing something with the Gelato network but Tenderly is also a good option, perhaps also Block Native
We‚Äôre trying to encode a random string (nft metadata) and decode if the user holds the token. Anything in the docs you can point to? <@399725459455213579> ?
here's how the access control condition should look: https://developer.litprotocol.com/AccessControlConditions/EVM/basicExamples#must-posess-a-specific-erc721-token-nft
this guide might also be helpful <@814847668706082837> - https://blog.litprotocol.com/?p=lit-x-bundlr-x-arweave-guide

üëÄ **ABOUT**
**Lit Protocol** lets you create and manage distributed cryptographic key-pairs for condition-based encryption and programmatic signing. A decentralized key management network, Lit can be used in place of centralized key custodians and other key management solutions.

Hello? What is the best tutorial or codes to learn about LitActions Mint/Grant/Burn pattern? I've been trying to use `getlit` cli. I could mint PKP but haven't tried mint/grant/burn yet. To do this, should I call PKP contract directly?

Hey moti, 

You can read about it in our docs
https://developer.litprotocol.com/litactions/usingpkpsandactions/#what-is-mintgrantburn

 and check out the code here
https://github.com/LIT-Protocol/LitNodeContracts/blob/main/contracts/PKPNFT.sol#L151-L157
Not exactly a guide, but you can see this in production with the yacht labs repo: https://yachtlabs.io/blog/yacht-lit-swap
Thank you for the resources! Could you tell me what is `keyType` in the argument of `mintGrantAndBurnNext`, if you don't mind?

<@399725459455213579> correct me if I'm wrong 

Correction: 

keyType should always be 2 because that's the only one we support

Check out the yacht example:  #2 
https://github.com/Yacht-Labs/yacht-lit-sdk/commit/2f6443a96e303cfbebccd66a381ac1366d4f4413

i think you mean base58 decode.  it's already base58 encoded üôÇ

Hey, accessControlConditions, encryptedSymmetricKey, and the encryptedString can be public (because they are encrypted) so all a user need to do is to pass in their authSig in order to decrypt the content

Hi <@806453232028876811> 
"Is there a best practice for distributing keys to multiple people with one encrypted target?"
You can provide the user's with the encryptedSymmetricKey since only the users who satisfy the accessControlCondition (that you set) can decrypt the content
<@806453232028876811> You may also use the `encryptToIpfs` function to encrypt & store the metadata on IPFS in one-go: https://developer.litprotocol.com/SDK/Explanation/encryption#encrypttoipfs
<@806453232028876811> You may use this ACC for checking whether a user owns a specific NFT: https://developer.litprotocol.com/accessControl/EVM/basicExamples#must-posess-a-specific-erc721-token-nft

I see.
Is there an API to perform the passing of authSig on-chain?

Why do you want to pass the authSig on chain?
Though you can pass it as a param to a contract function

For decryption/encrypting a content the user just has to pass the authSig to the litNodeClient Active instance. Like this: https://developer.litprotocol.com/SDK/Explanation/encryption#saving-the-encrypted-content-to-the-lit-nodes

hey! you can read more about that here: https://www.notion.so/litprotocol/Cloudflare-x-Lit-post-be67613ee77548fc93bf65fe6c739e04?pvs=4

TDLR: 
In the example, a Tesla OAuth credential is encrypted twice, once by Lit Protocol and a second time through Cloudflare. Both are necessary to decrypt the credentials; neither has access without the correct passkeys and order of decryption. This pattern is an interdependent system that can not work unless all pieces are in place. Individually, Lit Protocol can not unlock the car and Cloudflare also can not unlock the car.
hey Alexey, at this moment we do not have a method to extract the private key

A sample use case is; once I have encrypted the file I'd expect only a specific set of users to  decrypt it. 

So, I guess the question is how could those privileged users gain access to the key?

so you set the access control conditions before you encrypt the file - something like `user must own a doodles NFT to decrypt the content`

You can read more here: https://developer.litprotocol.com/accessControl/intro

Lit is a MPC key management network, so essentially as a developer you're relying on the Lit nodes to take care of the keys for you and the access to the decryption key is based on the access control conditions you've set

Hey, is it possible to gate a smart contract to only allow signatures that have been signed in a Lit Action ?
thanks!  here to answer any questions if you have them
yes, absolutely

you would want to mint a PKP with the Lit Action as the only auth method for it, and then put the corresponding public key from that PKP in your smart contract.  and then the lit action will use the lit nodes to sign whatever you want, and you can check the signature against the pubkey in the contract.
